before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"e9hss","text":"This protocol enables spatial detection of AAV genomes and concatemers in tissue. For detection of AAV genomes, a Zombie barcode and phage RNA polymerase promoter are required in a single AAV genome. For detection of AAV concatemers (SpECTr), 2 AAV genomes are required: one genome carries a Zombie barcode and the other carries a phage RNA polymerase promoter. Barcode sequences can be found in Supplementary Table 1 of Askary et al., Nat Biotechnol 38: 66.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":436,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"18iuc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"66ekj","text":"See https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.12.23.573214v1 for more information on these methods. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":4,"length":59}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"ECFE7F447B8211EFA0560A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.12.23.573214v1"}}}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4bvbt","text":"Detection of AAV genomes in situ can facilitate understanding of AAV transduction and processing. This protocol enables spatial detection of AAV genomes and concatemers in tissue and is based on the Zombie method published in Askary et al., Nat Biotechnol 38: 66. AAVs carrying barcoded genomes are delivered to cells. Following fixation, a phage RNA polymerase is used to transcribe the barcode in situ, yielding barcoded transcripts that can be detected with RNA FISH. This protocol is compatible with either ssAAV or scAAV genomes. In the former case, detected genomes will be primarily nuclear and detectable once second strand synthesis has occurred. In the latter case, the genome can be detected regardless of where in the transduction pathway the genome is. This protocol can be combined with RNA FISH detection of reporter transcripts or endogenous transcripts, enabling measurement of expression and cell type classification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":25,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":241,"length":17},{"style":"italic","offset":396,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"73fp2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2kkfe","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cremt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ccntt","text":"Collection time is dependent upon experimental question. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6357m","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":171,"style":"italic"}],"key":"4je01","text":"MAA fixes cells by causing proteins to precipitate, but will not crosslink molecules. {"blocks":[{"key":"dbc51","text":"Transduce animals with AAVs carrying Zombie barcode and phage RNA polymerase promoter (barcode sequences can be found in Supplementary Table 1 of Askary et al., Nat Biotechnol 38: 66).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":161,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ebibj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b5frq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"alnf6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":17,"offset":441,"style":"italic"}],"key":"34kqm","text":"This protocol enables spatial detection of both AAV genomes and concatemers in tissue. For detection of AAV genomes, a Zombie barcode and phage RNA polymerase promoter are required in a single AAV genome. For detection of AAV concatemers (SpECTr), 2 AAV genomes are required: one genome carries a Zombie barcode and the other carries a phage RNA polymerase promoter. Barcode sequences can be found in Supplementary Table 1 of Askary et al., Nat Biotechnol 38: 66.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eme1t","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6fhtm","text":"We have used this protocol to detect scAAV and ssAAV genomes and concatemers, delivered systemically to animals by AAV9, AAV-PHP.eB and AAV.CAP-B10.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"37he9","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":17,"offset":258,"style":"italic"}],"key":"5sh2c","text":"In choosing a phage RNA polymerase and promoter, we have relied primarily on T7. We have also used SP6 RNA polymerase successfully, but this yields smaller size spots. We have not tested T3 RNA polymerase in this application, but according to Askary et al., Nat Biotechnol 38: 66, this should yield similar results to T7 RNA polymerase. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

This fixation step occurs after tissue is flash-frozen and sliced. Thus, planning to use AAV-Zombie for detection of AAV genomes in an animal does not preclude other analyses performed on that animal. E.g. some pieces of tissue may be processed for AAV-Zombie, some post-fixed for standard IHC, and some dissociated for single cell analyses. {"blocks":[{"key":"b4mjf","text":"Begin tissue collection.  Euthanize animals according to your lab's approved protocol, then transcardially perfuse animals with   of heparinized PBS. For AAV-Zombie, dissect tissue into small blocks (max size 0.5 cm x 0.5 cm x 0.5 cm), then place into embedding mold. Using a clean pipette tip, gently position tissue. Once the mold is full, add enough O.C.T. compound to cover the tissue, then lower the mold into the dry ice-ethanol slurry. Be careful not to let any ethanol spill into the O.C.T. Once the entire block is frozen, transfer the block to dry ice (or to a   freezer).
